metadata.title: All About Heatmaps. The Comprehensive Guide | by Shrashti Singhal | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Everything possible about Heatmaps, techniques you wouldn't like to miss.

all_paragraphs: 8. Best Practices of using HeatMaps
11. How to Read a Seaborn Heat map
14. Create a default Heatmap using Seaborn
17. Generating colormap from seaborn Palletes
19. Exploratory data analysis (EDA) with the heatmap

Heatmaps visualize the data in a 2-dimensional format in the form of colored maps. The color maps use hue, saturation, or luminance to achieve color variation to display various details. This color variation gives visual cues to the readers about the magnitude of numeric values. HeatMaps is about replacing numbers with colors because the human brain understands visuals better than numbers, text, or any written data. Human beings are visual learners; therefore, visualizing the data in any form makes more sense. Heatmaps represent data in an easy-to-understand manner. Thus visualizing methods like HeatMaps have become popular.

Heatmaps can describe the density or intensity of variables, visualize patterns, variance, and even anomalies. Heatmaps show relationships between variables. These variables are plotted on both axes. We look for patterns in the cell by noticing the color change. It only accepts numeric data and plots it on the grid, displaying different data values by varying color intensity.
Typically, there are two types of Heatmaps:

o Clustered Heatmap: The goal of Clustered Heatmap is to build associations between both the data points and their features. This type of heatmap implements clustering as part of the process of grouping similar features. Clustered Heatmaps are widely used in biological sciences for studying gene similarities across individuals.

The order of the rows in Clustered Heatmap is determined by performing hierarchical cluster analysis of the rows. Clustering positions similar rows together on the map. Similarly, the order of the columns is determined.

o Correlogram: A correlogram replaces each of the variables on the two axes with numeric variables in the dataset. Each square depicts the relationship between the two intersecting variables, which helps to build descriptive or predictive statistical models.
Heat maps are used by any organization that collects and uses data to improve their finances, sales, operations, customer service, or marketing.
Some of the industries that use Heatmaps:³

Choropleth maps are sometimes confused with heat maps. A choropleth map features different shading patterns within geographic boundaries to show the proportion of a variable of interest². In contrast, a heat map does not correspond to geographic boundaries. Choropleth maps visualize the variability of a variable across a geographic area or within a region. A heat map uses regions drawn according to the variable’s pattern, rather than the a priori geographic areas of choropleth maps¹. The Choropleth is aggregated into well-known geographic units, such as countries, states, provinces, and counties.

Many different color schemes can illustrate the heat map, with perceptual advantages and disadvantages for each. The color palette choices are more than just aesthetics because the colors in the HeatMap reveal patterns in the data. Good color schemes can enhance pattern discovery, and poor color choices can hide it.

The seaborn Heatmaps are the grid Heatmaps that can take various types of data and generate heatmaps. The primary purpose of the seaborn heatmap is to show the correlation matrix by data visualization. It helps find the relationship between multiple features and which features are best for Machine Learning model building.

A correlation matrix denotes the correlation coefficients between variables at the same time. A heat map grid can represent these coefficients to build a visual representation of the variables’ dependence. This visualization makes it easy to spot the strong dependencies. A positive correlation indicates a strong dependency, while a negative correlation indicates a strong inverse dependency; a correlation coefficient closer to zero indicates weak dependence.

The heatmap transforms the correlation matrix into color codings. The correlation matrix shows how the variables are correlated to each other on a scale of -1 to 1. 1 being positively correlated and -1 being inversely correlated. As only numerical features can show the correlation, the heatmap cannot visualize categorical features. Strings need to be encoded to be pictured on the Heatmaps.
Three input types for the heatmap⁸
To understand each argument in the heatmap function, please refer to the following Document.⁷
Heatmap takes one mandatory parameter: ‘data.’ The CSV format dataset is downloaded from the below link.
cmap parameter can take matplotlib colormap name or object, or list of colors.
The currently available Matplotlib colormap names are listed below:⁹
Seaborn Color Palletes: The Color Palletes are a full range of digital colors used for visualizations using seaborn.

The seaborn function color_palette() provides an interface to generate color palettes in seaborn. The argument to color_palette() can be Name of a seaborn palette (deep, muted, bright, pastel, dark, colorblind), Name of matplotlib colormap, ‘ch:<cubehelix arguments>’, ‘husl’ or ‘hsl’, ‘light:<color>’, ‘dark:<color>’, ‘blend:<color>,<color>’, or A sequence of colors in any format matplotlib accepts
set_palette() function sets the default palette, which calls color_palette() internally, and accepts the same arguments.
The most straightforward approach to find unique hues is to draw evenly-spaced colors in a circular color space for an arbitrary number of categories; HSL & HUSL color space uses this approach.

o Perceptually uniform palettes: Seaborn includes four perceptually uniform sequential colormaps: “rocket”, “mako”, “flare”, and “crest”. The first two have a vast luminance range and are well suited for applications such as heatmaps.

o Sequential cubehelix palettes: The cubehelix system offers an RGB-based tradeoff, which generates sequential palettes with a linear increase or decrease in brightness with some continuous variation in hue. The resulting colormaps are not perfectly perceptually uniform but have a parameterizable design process. cubehelix_palette() control how the palette looks.
o Custom sequential palettes: Both light_palette() or dark_palette() are passed a single color value, which produces a palette that starts either from light or dark desaturated values to that color.
o Sequential Color Brewer palettes: The Color Brewer library for sequential palettes include palettes with one primary hue.
o Perceptually uniform diverging palettes: Seaborn has two perceptually uniform diverging palettes: “vlag” and “icefire.”

o Custom diverging palettes: diverging_palette() is used to create a custom colormap for diverging data. It builds the colormaps with one color on each side. It needs two colors as arguments, converging to another color in the center. Correlations range from -1 to 1, so they have two directions, and in this case, a diverging palette works better than a sequential one.
Cubehelix palette is a sequential palate. Cmap can take matplot colormaps or seaborn palette as arguments. We can use both of the cubehelix colors in our Heatmap
A colormap can be generated by a pre-built function with a blend of either light or dark values.
· Light palette colormap: It merges the given color from light to dark, representing the data from low to high values.
· Dark palette colormap: It mixes the given color from dark to light, representing the data from low to high values.
The seaborn.mpl_palette() function can visualize the discrete values by generating a discrete palette.
· Set3: Name of the color palette
· 20: Number of discrete colors to be presented in a palette.

Parameters vmin & vmax are used to change the colormap's limits, which adjust the lower and upper contrast bounds. Everything below vmin and everything above vmax will be of the same colors, respectively.
vmin and vmax are set to lie outside of the range of the data for a washed-out look.
cmap values are set to change the default colormap value.
Data is centered on ‘0’ on a default colormap. The center can be changed by setting the ‘center’ parameter of the colormap to a specific value.
Robust remove vmin or vmax using sns.heatmap() robust parameter. The ‘robust’ works like an “auto-contrast” for choosing good values by fixing contrast levels based on quartiles.
Annot parameter fills the cells with the relative correlation coefficient, which ranges from -1 to 1.

The ‘annot’ only adds numeric value on the python heatmap cell, but the ‘fmt’ parameter allows us to change these annotations' format and significantly add string (text) values. For string values, ‘annot’ should contain an array of strings, and ‘fmt’ should be ‘s.’
The default scientific notation is 2g. Fmt accepts the below values:

Sometimes annot and fmt parameter is not sufficient to generate a meaningful and stylish Heatmap. For formatting of cell annotations, such as the font size, font color, font orientation, etc., can be done by annot_kws. The ‘annot_kws’ means annotate keyword arguments, which help change the style and formatting of annotating text.
The ‘annot_kws’ accepts all ‘ax.text’ or ‘matplotlib.text’ arguments. For passing annot_kws, then annot value must be True.⁷
Increase or decrease line width between each cell by the ‘linewidth’ parameter.

Sometimes the ‘linewidth’ parameter fails to divide the heatmap cell because of color complexity. The ‘linecolor’ parameter gives the flexibility to choose any color for the heatmap line. The ‘linewidth’ parameter is mandatory to set the ‘linecolor.’ For the list of colors, refer to the following document.
The legend or ‘cbar’ is visible by default. It doesn’t make much sense of heatmap without the key. Still, if the key is not needed, ‘cbar’ is set to ‘False.’
The color bar keyword arguments (cbar_kws) parameter can accept multiple keyword arguments as a dictionary. The ‘cbar_kws’ accepts all matplotlib color bar parameters.⁷
ax and cbar_ax are used to plot heatmap and cbar on separate axes.
The ‘ax’ is also used to set various axes level functions such as title, x label, y label, etc.
‘square’ parameter is used to shape the Heatmap cells as squares. The ‘square’ forces the aspect ratio of the blocks to be equal.
To set the labels on X-axis and Y-axis, ‘xticklabel’ and ‘yticklabel’ parameters are used.⁷
Rotation of label ticks is possible by using the ‘rotation’ parameter.
To rotate the default labels, ‘get_yticklabels()’ or ‘get_xticklabels()’ is used to get the default labels, then rotation is set to an angle value.

The entire heatmap can be divided into two triangles, the upper triangle and the lower triangle. Both the triangle provides a complete set of information alone. Therefore it is redundant to plot the entire heatmap. It is preferred to plot either of the triangles.
To mask the upper triangle, ‘triu,’ a numPy method is used. To hide the lower triangle, ‘tril,’ a numPy method is used.

To hide specific values, the condition to hide the desired values is passed in the ‘mask’ parameter. Here, we are masking every alternate row starting from row 1 and every alternate column starting from column 0.
The ‘kwargs’ is used to pass other keyword arguments, generally not available in seaborn such as rasterized, edge color, cap-style, etc. It allows all keyword arguments of matplotlib ‘ax.pcolormesh.’
Kwargs accepts a dictionary as an argument.
The set_style() interface can be used for manipulating the styles. It helps to set the theme of the plot. There are five themes available:
The top and right axis spines can be removed using the despine() function in the white and ticks themes.
The Heatmap scale can be controlled by using the set_context() function or set_theme() function. Based on relative size, there are four pre-set templates for contexts:
By default, the context is the notebook.
The font size of all the seaborn components can be changed using Seaborn's ‘font_scale’ attribute. The default scale is ‘1’.
Multiple Heatmaps can be generated using the matplotlib plt.subplot() function.

Regular Heatmaps makes it easy to distinguish between negative correlation, positive correlation, and no correlation features, but to examine the values of positive correlation among positively correlated variables still require us to go over the grid multiple times.
To make our maps more readable, in addition to color, we add size as a parameter to our heatmap. The size of each colored square is proportional to the magnitude of the correlation.
It also gives intuition about the marginal distributions without the need to refer to a color legend. There is no feature in seaborn for this; we will use corrplot from biokit.

This type of heatmap implements clustering as part of the process of grouping similar features. Inherently Clustering algorithms are used to arrange similar rows together on the map. Similarly, the order of the columns is determined.

Thank you for reading this article. I believe I have covered all the possible content related to Heatmaps. Let me know if I have missed any in the comments. You can also explore the colab notebook containing the above examples and more. Till then, Happy Learning. Tia
